Diem Cabinet. In 1963 he split with Diem and was
"exiled" to Washington. Following the fall of Diem in
November of 1963, Mr. Dinh returned to South Vietnam. He remained in the South Vietnamese Foreign
Service, his career field, and represented his governtnent in Argentina and India.

and work in Washington, D.C. as a journalist, author,
poet and lecturer. He served for a time as American
Editor for the Saigon Post.

Germs Under The Microscope
Bacteriological warfare research is going on at
Hopkins. The fact has been investigated and reported in
several national magazines as well as in the News-Letter.
President Milton Eisenhower's press statement on the
matter Wednesday was merely a further confirmation of
the fact.
The subject of bacteriological warfare research has
been considered a highly touchy topic ever since the end
of the First World War, when the research went underground. The Army, and participating institutions such
as Hopkins, have kept the matter of bacteriological warfare research under the strictest security for two reasons—that it is in the national interest, and that it may
cause overly antagonistic public opinion. We will not
argue whether such research is in the national interest,
nor shall we argue the reasons involved in the pursuit of
such research. The matter of importance here is the
fact that Hopkins, a private educational institution,' is
Involved in bacteriological warfare research.
The research at Hopkins, both at the Medical Institutions and elsewhere, started more than a decade ago,
and its extent is positively pandemic. The press statement released Wednesday was a whitewash. In the release it was stated that $30 million was the total for
Government connected research — unfortunately the
figure is $80 million to all Hopkins institutions. The administration statement further claimed that only one per
cent of the work is classified—the actual number of research reports available only with security clearance exceeds one per cent. Bacteriological warfare research is
included in this classified category.
The argument given to defend BW research is that
it deals "exclusively with the diagnosis, pathogenesis,
and epidemiology of infectious diseases that might resuit from exposure to either biological or chemical warfare agents. . All research has been 'defensive' in
character and any implication to the contrary is false."
That the word "defensive" is singled out in the state.
ment is indicative of die lack of conviction it carries.
:What are defensive and offensive weapons? An overwhelming number of experts in the field state that there
can be no differentiation between the two—especially
in connection with germ and chemical warfare. A high
ranking officr connected with the research has admitted
that no division can be made between a morally justiable defensive weapon and the more odious use of offensive germ weapons. In light of the facts this "defensive" argument is demolished, anti yet the Hopkins
community is warned not to heed arguments against
bacteriological research with the desperate remark that
"any implication to the contrary is false." President
Eisenhower's statement to the press about bacteriological
warfare is an inaccurate reply to concerned students and
faculty.
Research belongs in the University anti makes up
a vital part of both the educational anti service roles
that Hopkins plays. But an educational institution must
also keep in mind the premise upon which it has been
founded—to enrich and expand the mind of men for
the good of other men. Research pursued with the goal
of "utilization for incapacitation", as the Army Research
Task Summary describes it, does not belong at this
University. If the Government wishes to conduct bacteriological research it should buy out the labs and the
scientists and do the work on its own. A university is
not in the business of destroying life, it is engaged in
the practice of 'saving and enriching life. It is particu.
larly ironic that some of the B.W. research is going on
In the Department of Pathology at the world renowned
Hopkins Medical Institutions.
The relationship between the Government and the
higher educational system in the United States enters

Germs Under The Microscope
Bacteriological warfare research is going on at
Hopkins. The fact has been investigated and reported in
several national magazines as well as in the News-Letter.
President Milton Eisenhower's press statement on the
matter Wednesday was merely a further confirmation of
the fact.
The subject of bacteriological warfare research has
been considered a highly touchy topic ever since the end
of the First World War, when the research went underground. The Army, and participating institutions such
as Hopkins, have kept the matter of bacteriological warfare research under the strictest security for two reasons—that it is in the national interest, and that it may
cause overly antagonistic public opinion. We will not
argue whether such research is in the national interest,
nor shall we argue the reasons involved in the pursuit of
such research. The matter of importance here is the
fact that Hopkins, a private educational institution,' is
Involved in bacteriological warfare research.
The research at Hopkins, both at the Medical Institutions and elsewhere, started more than a decade ago,
and its extent is positively pandemic. The press statement released Wednesday was a whitewash. In the release it was stated that $30 million was the total for
Government connected research — unfortunately the
figure is $80 million to all Hopkins institutions. The administration statement further claimed that only one per
cent of the work is classified—the actual number of research reports available only with security clearance exceeds one per cent. Bacteriological warfare research is
included in this classified category.
The argument given to defend BW research is that
it deals "exclusively with the diagnosis, pathogenesis,
and epidemiology of infectious diseases that might resuit from exposure to either biological or chemical warfare agents. . All research has been 'defensive' in
character and any implication to the contrary is false."
That the word "defensive" is singled out in the state.
ment is indicative of die lack of conviction it carries.
:What are defensive and offensive weapons? An overwhelming number of experts in the field state that there
can be no differentiation between the two—especially
in connection with germ and chemical warfare. A high
ranking officr connected with the research has admitted
that no division can be made between a morally justiable defensive weapon and the more odious use of offensive germ weapons. In light of the facts this "defensive" argument is demolished, anti yet the Hopkins
community is warned not to heed arguments against
bacteriological research with the desperate remark that
"any implication to the contrary is false." President
Eisenhower's statement to the press about bacteriological
warfare is an inaccurate reply to concerned students and
faculty.
Research belongs in the University anti makes up
a vital part of both the educational anti service roles
that Hopkins plays. But an educational institution must
also keep in mind the premise upon which it has been
founded—to enrich and expand the mind of men for
the good of other men. Research pursued with the goal
of "utilization for incapacitation", as the Army Research
Task Summary describes it, does not belong at this
University. If the Government wishes to conduct bacteriological research it should buy out the labs and the
scientists and do the work on its own. A university is
not in the business of destroying life, it is engaged in
the practice of 'saving and enriching life. It is particu.
larly ironic that some of the B.W. research is going on
In the Department of Pathology at the world renowned
Hopkins Medical Institutions.
The relationship between the Government and the
higher educational system in the United States enters
into this discussion. The Government is the largest single
contributer to colleges and universities in both institutional financing and research contracts. Government
financing is often beneficial both to the institutions and
the Government. There arise, however, several dangers—
conflict of interest and Government manipulation of
higher education, among others. Germ and chemical
warfare research is not in our sphere of interest, if not
antithetical to Mir avowed interests and goals. The danger
of Government manipulation following on the heels of
heavy Government support of education is a disturbing
corollary attached to research contracts.
We urge the administration to reject research contracts dealing with bacteriological warfare and put the
laboratories at the Medical Institutions to better use. If
prompt action from the Hopkins administration is not
forthcoming, we hope that the faculty will not betray
the trust of their profession and that the students will
not ignore their sense of duty.
